data.name: Deferred calculations.  Simple version.
data.description:
## We use the capabilities of C ++ 17.

1. We create a function **make_lazy** that receives a functor and arguments to call this functor, and returns an object.
2. When accessing this object by methods **call**, the function value is calculated with the given arguments.

## Simple:
1. Functor arguments - only values (not other functors, not pointers, not references).
2. Return values - only values (not functors, not pointers).
3. At least three solutions are known (When using various objects of the standard library).

## PS: For multiple calls, you can cache the result.


Examples:
```
auto f1 = make_lazy([](auto x, auto y) {return 2 * x + y; }, 2, 3);
auto r1 = f1.call(); // r1 == 7

auto f2 = make_lazy([](auto x, auto y, auto z) {return 2 * x + y - z; }, 2.1, 3.0, 0.5);
auto r2 = f1.call(); // r2 == 6.7

auto f3 = make_lazy([](void) {return std::vector<int>(10, 10); });
auto r3 = f3.call(); // r3 == {10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10}
```
Attention: function call is not always carried out!

```
#include <vector>
auto f4 = make_lazy([](auto size) {return std::vector<int>(size, 0)}, 1000000);
```
